main_text:
Alfred Schutz (b. 1899, d. 1959), more than any other phenomenologist,
attempted to relate the thought of Edmund Husserl to the social world
and the social sciences. His Phenomenology of the Social
World supplied philosophical foundations for Max Weber’s
sociology and for economics, with which he was familiar through
contacts with colleagues of the Austrian school. When Schutz fled
Hitler’s Anschluss of Austria and immigrated to the
United States in 1939, he developed his thought further in
relationship to the social sciences, American pragmatism, logical
empiricism, and to various other fields of endeavor such as music and
literature. His work has been influential on new movements in
sociological thought such as ethnomethodology and conversation
analysis.
